Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the increase in the national debt under Barack Obama by stating that he "doubled our national debt" when it actually increased by less than double.
Understate: The claim understates the amount of the national debt by stating that it will be "close to $20 trillion" when Obama leaves, when in fact it was already $19.5 trillion at the time of the statement.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge that factors beyond Obama's actions, such as the Great Recession and Congress's role in passing spending bills, also contributed to the increase in the national debt.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to fully substantiate the assertion that Obama is solely to blame for the rise in the national debt.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the national debt did increase during Obama's presidency, but not to the extent of being doubled.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Obama is solely responsible for the rise in the national debt without considering other factors or the role of Congress.
